main_text:
Early Nineteenth-Century Transformism || Transformism in Britain 1830–1859
4.3 Transformism in Britain 1830–1859

Discussions of transformism in the British Isles in the pre-Darwinian
period were influenced particularly by the French reflections and the
French debates taking place at the Muséum. Following
the cessation of the Napoleonic Wars in 1814–15, extensive new
contacts developed between French and British scientists, particularly
through Edinburgh (Corsi 2021, Jenkins 2011). In addition to French
connections, there were also important personal contacts between
German and British scientists that also included the introduction of
German progressive developmentalism and transcendental anatomy in the
early decades of the nineteenth century both through Edinburgh, and
also directly into London scientific circles. The recognition of these
new introductions of French and German science and intellectual
traditions into the British Isles, particularly moving through medical
contexts, has supplied a new framework for understanding the
reflections on species change in Britain in the period before the
advent of Darwin’s work (Rupke 2009; R. J. Richards 2002; Sloan,
2003, 1992b; Desmond 1989).

The Edinburgh comparative anatomist, Robert Edmond Grant (1793–
1874), played an important role in introducing the French discussions
into the British Isles. He would also serve as Charles Darwin’s
first mentor in science when Darwin was a young medical student at the
University of Edinburgh (1825–27). Grant was directly engaged
with the issues being debated at the time between Geoffroy St.
Hilaire, Cuvier and Lamarck, and he advocated a variant of a
Lamarckian-Geoffroyean transformism in his writings, themes expounded
in his lectures on comparative anatomy at the new University College,
London where he became the first professor of comparative anatomy in
1827 (Desmond 1989). In addition to Grant, several other naturalists
in Edinburgh brought French discussions into the British context
(Corsi 2021, Jenkins 2011).
4.3.1 The Lyellian Critique of Lamarckism

These French-inspired discussions of transformism entering mainly
through Edinburgh were subjected to a powerful critique by the Scots
lawyer turned geologist, Charles Lyell (1797–1875). In a
discussion that occupied seventeen of eighteen chapters (282 pages) of
the second volume (1832) of his landmark three-volume Principles
of Geology (1830–33), Lyell subjected Lamarckian theory to
a multi-level critique that was to influence much of the subsequent
opposition to transformism in British circles, and posed a wide range
of issues that Charles Darwin had to overcome subsequently. 

Opening with five chapters that analyzed Lamarck’s assumptions
about species instability and summarizing his causal explanations of
both the serial ascent of life and the plasticity of form and function
under the influence of internal causes, Lyell developed a withering
attack on Lamarckism. In this discussion he questioned the empirical
evidence for species transformism, both in terms of evidence from
natural species, and also the warrant that could be drawn from changes
that have been produced in domestic animals and plants by human
activity. Moving beyond this, he then questioned the evidence for
connections of living forms across biogeographical regions, and the
evidence for substantial change in historical migrations between zones
of habitation. 

A second level of critique concerned the evidence assumed by Lamarck
(and Geoffroy) for historical progressionism in the forms of life,
with oldest rocks showing simplest forms, and subsequent geological
formations (Secondary, Tertiary) showing the appearance of higher and
more complex forms eventually resulting in the mammals. This theme of
geological progress, embraced not only by transformists, but also by
British disciples of Cuvier, was attacked by Lyell with an argument
that would later be used by Darwin to different ends—the
imperfection of the geological record. In Lyell’s view, the
accidents of fossilization undercut any inference from the fossil
record concerning an assumption of the historical development of life.
Against speculations of Lamarck and others concerning evidence for a
progression from simpler forms to those now existing, Lyell replies
with reference to plant evidence that,


Those naturalists, therefore, who infer that the ancient flora of the
globe was, at certain periods, less varied than now, merely because
they have as yet discovered only a few hundred fossil species of a
particular epoch, while they can enumerate more than fifty thousand
living ones, are reasoning on a false basis…: (Lyell 1832
[1991], 245; see also p. 20).


In examining these issues, Lyell concludes that empirical evidence
only supports a claim of limited transformations of a varietal level
that remains within natural species boundaries. In Lyell’s
conclusion, there was no empirical support for the transfomism of
species.
4.3.2: German Philosophy of Nature and British Developmentalism

In addition to French-inspired developments of transformism that Lyell
focused on in his critique of Lamarck, a lesser-studied introduction
of German philosophy of nature and German reflections on anatomical
resemblance formed a different current of reflection with significant
consequences for the mid-nineteenth century discussions of the
transformist question in the British Isles. The cessation of the
Napoleonic hostilities was accompanied by the introduction into
British discussions of German scientific thought along with
expositions of the systematic philosophies of Kant, Fichte, Hegel and
Schelling (Sloan 2003). With relevance to species transformism,
Schelling-inspired themes in the philosophy of nature were expounded
in the Hunterian Lectures in Comparative Anatomy at the Royal College
of Surgeons in London, delivered by the British surgeon Joseph Henry
Green (1791–1863). Green utilized dimensions of
Schelling’s Naturphilosophie to develop in his lectures
between 1820–27 a dynamic theory of group relations which
synthesized the work of Lamarck, Cuvier, and the University of
Göttingen medical theorist Johann Blumenbach (1752–1840
(Sloan, 1992b, 2007), relations which he even depicted in tree-like
branchings of relationship that went beyond those of Lamarck.



Figure 2: Joseph Henry Green’s
diagram of the relations of the invertebrate and vertebrate groups in
1827 as represented in the notes of Richard Owen. [An
 extended description of figure 2
 is in the supplement.] 


These themes would be continued in the major series of lectures
delivered by Green’s protégé at the College of
Surgeons, the comparative anatomist, Richard Owen (1804–92), who
was named to the prestigious Hunterian Chair in Comparative Anatomy
1837 and remained in that position until 1856 (Rupke 1994, 1993; Sloan
1992b) 

Owen’s widely-attended London lectures delivered between 1837
and 1856 brought many of the issues of comparative anatomy,
classication, fossil evidence, and embryology to bear on the questions
of species relationship and change. In these lectures, presented
against the backdrop of the massive anatomical collections of the
Hunterian Museum in London, Owen developed a reinterpretation of the
significance of the Cuvier-Geoffroy dispute and developed its
implications for issues surrounding the historical development of the
vertebrates as represented in this diagram he made in 1837. 



Figure 3: Richard Owen’s
representation of the relation of the main animal groups in February,
1837. [An
 extended description of figure 3
 is in the supplement.] 


As a solution to the Cuvier-Geoffroy issues, Owen subsequently
developed in his Hunterian lectures in 1845 the theory of the
archetypal vertebrate that connected the anatomical relations of all
the vertebrates, a theme he then elaborated in an important set of
publications in 1847 and 1849 (Owen, 1847, 1849 [2007]). Employing
aspects of William Whewell’s philosophy of science to develop
these arguments, Owen expounded the theory of the unity of type in
relation to the Cuvierian analysis of the relation of form and
function. In his argument, the archetype, functioning both as a
transcendental ideal form and also as an immanent law working in the
material history of life, explained the progression and
differentiation of the vertebrates in historical time ((Sloan 2003; R.
J. Richards 2002: chp. 14; Rupke 1993). 



Figure 4: Richard Owen’s depiction
of the Archetypal Vertebrate, composed of a series of ideal vertebrae
as in his On the Nature of the Limbs (1849),
“Appendix”. [An
 extended description of figure 4
 is in the supplement.] 


By means of this theory, Owen claimed he could coherently explain both
the deep resemblance of forms in their internal anatomy—the
theme emphasized by Geoffroy St. Hilaire—, and also the close
fitting of structure and function to the organism’s
“conditions of existence”, the insight emphasized by
Cuvier.

To distinguish these two meanings of relationship, Owen introduced
into the literature in 1843 a crucial distinction between resemblances
of “homology”, meaning the presence of the
“same” parts in every variety of form and
function—Geoffroyean relationships—and those of
“analogy”, denoting solely the similarity of parts in
their functional adaptations—Cuvierian relationships. Developing
this concept of homology in relation to his theory of the archetype,
Owen claimed he could at last give a coherent meaning to the concept
of “sameness” in anatomical relationships—the
warrant for speaking, for example, of a “femur” in a bird
and a mammal as the “same” bone in different forms and
functions. Furthermore, as Owen developed this theory in relation to
his work on the fossil record, the theory of the archetype, conceived
also as an immanent law working in history, led Owen to embrace a
concept of branching and diversifying relations of forms in history as
divergences from this ideal archetypal form over time
 (fig. 3
 above). Owen thus broke with the linear historical progressionism
from simple to complex assumed in several transformist theories. 

On the other hand, Owen’s model cannot be considered to
represent genuine species transformism—species do not change
historically one into another and the archetype exists as a
quasi-Newtonian ideal “law” governing development in time
rather than designating an actual historical form that materially has
given rise to successive forms displaying homologous relationships.
Nonetheless, his integration of comparative anatomy, paleontology, and
even embryology into this framework, set out a sophisticated model of
relationship that was later reinterpreted by Darwin from the viewpoint
of his theory of material derivation from common historical
ancestors.
4.3.3 Popular Transformism in Britain, 1844–1859

On a more popular level, species transformism was broadly popularized
in pre-Darwinian Anglophone discussions by the appearance in 1844 of
the grand evolutionary cosmology put forth anonymously by the Scottish
publisher Robert Chambers (1802–71) in his immensely popular
Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation (Chambers
1844[1994]), a work which in many respects prepared Victorian society
in England, as well as pre-Civil War America, for Darwin’s more
restricted theory of 1859 (Secord 2000; MacPherson, 2015). More
similar to Buffon’s Epochs of Nature than to the
writings of Lamarck, Chambers proposed an evolutionary schema that
began with the nebular beginnings of the cosmos, the geological
history of the earth interpreted as a progression of ages, accompanied
by a historical progression of life from simple to complex, the cosmos
moved in a teleological direction up to humanity, with a broad
evolution of species up the chain of being. In this grand schema he
incorporated insights from French zoology and geological
progressionism, ignoring the refutations of this by Lyell, with all of
this working under the actions of one great unifying natural law that
demonstrated a great divine design of nature. This vision was further
popularized by its incorporation into Alfred Lord Tennyson’s
epic poem In Memoriam (1850). In spite of the popularity of
Chamber’s work, which went through eleven editions by the end of
the nineteenth century and sold more copies than Darwin’s
Origin of Species, the British scientific community was
essentially unanimous in its rejection of Chamber’s
speculations, with Lyellian and Cuvierian critiques forming a solid
scientific basis for these arguments. In many ways this opposition to
the Vestiges by leading members of the Victorian scientific
establishment formed one primary source of professional resistance to
the later Darwinian theory (see entry on Darwin: From the Origin
of Species to the Descent of Man, Section 3).

A more philosophically influential developmental evolutionism was also
advocated in pre-Darwinian England by the British railway engineer and
public intellectual, Herbert Spencer (1820–1903)
 (Herbert Spencer).
 Inspired both by the expositions of Lamarckianism by Charles Lyell in
the second volume of his Principles of Geology
(1830–33), by the writings of Karl Ernst von Baer on
embryological development, and also by Richard Owen’s Hunterian
Lectures on the osteology of the vertebrate skeleton, which Spencer
attended in 1851 (Rupke 1994: 206), Spencer entered the British
discussions of transformism in 1852 with his endorsement of the
“development hypothesis” (Spencer 1852). This initiated
his broad reflections on the law-governed evolution of society and
humanity, developed in detail in such works as First
Principles, published in 1862 (Haines 1988). Prior to the use of
the term by Darwin, Spencer spoke of the “evolution” of
life and the cosmos from material beginnings, with species changing as
a result of the operation of natural forces. It was also from Spencer
that Darwin borrowed the designator “survival of the
fittest” as a synonym for his own “natural
selection” in the fifth edition of the Origin of
Species in 1869. Although Spencer’s First
Principles appeared after the publication of Darwin’s
Origin, Spencer’s transformism was developed generally
independently of Darwin’s work and shows closest affinity with
the reflections of Lamarck, Chambers, and the historical
developmentalism of Owen.

Spencer, rather than Darwin, has often been seen as the primary
theoretician of “social” Darwinism in the late nineteenth
and early twentieth centuries (Hofstadter 1944 [1955]; see also the
entry on Herbert Spencer). Spencer’s world-wide influence even
made his works a vehicle by which Darwinism was first introduced into
non-Western discussions (Jin 2019, 2020; Lightman (ed.) 2016; Elshakry
2013; Pusey 1983). This unusual juxtapositioning of Spencer and Darwin
is explored in the entry
 Darwin: From the Origin of Species to the Descent of Man
 (Section 3.1).
hierarchy_title: Evolutionary Thought Before Darwin || Early Nineteenth-Century Transformism || Transformism in Britain 1830–1859
